<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/23/congress-approves-484b-relief-package-including-320b-ppp?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Let's Try This Again
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="PPPlinko game " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82OTMvcHBwbGlua28uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday evening, the House <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/23/us/coronavirus-live-news-coverage.html?action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">passed</a> a $484 billion supplement to the CARES Act, including $321 billion in fresh funds for small businesses through the Paycheck Protection Program.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now, you really have to <em>try </em>if you want to make people angry while doling out $350 billion in emergency cash, but the first edition of PPP managed to do that and more. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">No room for VIPPPs </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As if dealing with line-cutters at the grocery store isn’t bad enough, recent reports have exposed how big banks <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/22/business/sba-loans-ppp-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">prioritized</a> or offered unfair advantages to wealthy clients to secure PPP loans. Special treatment included "concierge" services and digital HOV lanes that zipped by clogged application portals. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Loans of $1 million or more accounted for 45% of total PPP distributions...but ended up in the hands of just 4% of recipients. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This time around,</strong> $60 billion will be <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/house-expected-pass-latest-coronavirus-aid-bill-thursday-n1190376?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">set aside</a> for mom-and-pop shops without a direct line to Midtown East. Many small businesses had better luck going through smaller/local banks in V1. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Keeping things private </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Publicly traded companies <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/public-companies-have-to-repay-small-business-rescue-loans-11587670442?mod=hp_lead_pos6&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">received</a> almost $600 million in PPP loans—and a very public flogging for doing so. Some recipients, including Shake Shack and the owner of Ruth’s Chris Steakhouse, have agreed to return the money. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Critics argue these companies can raise funds through other avenues unavailable to mom and pop. Just last week, Shake Shack was able to raise $150 million selling new shares.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But...they technically weren’t breaking any rules.</span><span><strong style="color:#000"> </strong></span><span>The National Restaurant Association </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-restaurant-hotel-chains-won-exemption-to-get-small-business-loans-11586167200?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lobbied</a></span><span> and helped secure exemptions from Congress for restaurants and hotel chains to access the PPP. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the SBA <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/23/small-business-loans-sba-203846?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">closed the loophole</a> and warned publicly traded companies they probably won't qualify for the new funds. The Treasury Department asked public companies to return their loans before May 7, or else face charges they weren’t acting “in good faith.”  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here:</strong> The SBA is currently not releasing detailed information about PPP recipients. However, the Fed (which also runs emergency small business lending programs) said yesterday it will <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-23/fed-to-name-participants-in-cares-act-backed-loan-programs?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">disclose</a> participants’ names, funding, and interest rates.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PHARMA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/23/gilead-defense-website-snafu?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
WHOops
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A document posted on the World Health Organization’s website yesterday delivered some <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2020/04/23/data-on-gileads-remdesivir-released-by-accident-show-no-benefit-for-coronavirus-patients/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">disappointing news</a>: Remdesivir, a potential COVID-19 treatment developed by biopharma company Gilead Sciences, did not improve patient outcomes in a randomized clinical trial.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>According to the summary, 13.9% of the patients who received the drug died after one month, versus 12.8% in a control group, </span><span><a href="https://www.ft.com/content/0a4872d1-4cac-4040-846f-ce32daa09d99?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the FT</a></span><span> and health news site Stat report. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The twist: </strong>The summary was quickly removed from the website. A WHO spokesperson said it was posted by mistake. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The study, a first-of-its-kind clinical trial in China, was stopped early because it didn’t have enough patients, so Gilead argued its results are inconclusive. Although Gilead did say “trends in the data suggest a potential benefit” for the drug. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So...what does it all mean? </strong>Not much—no definitive thumbs up or down for remdesivir yet. Several other ongoing studies will hopefully offer more conclusions.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FUNDRAISE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/23/companies-surging-struggling-tap-debt-markets?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Busy Borrowers
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="man diving into pool of money" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/lptjRBxFKCJmFoibP3/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="man diving into pool of money" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/lptjRBxFKCJmFoibP3/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Whether they’re seizing an opportunity presented by the coronavirus crisis or just hanging on for dear life, corporations were hyperactive in raising debt this week. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Netflix </strong>is offering <a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/netflix-raise-1-billion-debt-offering-1234587050/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$1 billion</a> in junk bonds to feed its quarantine content machine. The company reported astounding subscriber numbers for Q1 when its home screen became the only game in town.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Snap, </strong>also looking to pounce on the best quarter for scrolling ever, is <a href="https://www.axios.com/snapchat-debt-offering-750-million-raise-70d55da3-c8c7-4c5e-a5f4-eebb20a8dab2.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">planning to raise</a> up to $750 million in private debt. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Delta </strong>is planning to raise $3 billion in debt after <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-delta-air-offering/delta-to-raise-3-billion-in-debt-to-combat-virus-fallout-idUSKCN22500Q?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">forecasting</a> a 90% revenue drop in Q2. On the other side of the battered travel sector, <strong style="color:#000">Expedia </strong>is pulling in $2 billion in <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/23/expedia-raises-3-2b-to-ride-out-pandemic-names-new-ceo-and-announces-austerity-measures/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new debt financing</a> (along with $1.2 billion in private equity funding). The company also named vice chairman Peter Kern as CEO.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Macy’s </strong>is in perhaps even more trouble. Using its inventory and real estate as collateral, it’s considering raising as much as $5 billion in debt, <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/21/macys-weighs-raising-as-much-as-5-billion-in-debt-to-weather-coronavirus-crisis.html?mod=article_inline&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CNBC reports</a>. Macy’s has furloughed most of its 130,000 employees while all of its stores have been closed since March 18.</p>

<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s it, we’ve officially lounged on every surface in the house. The countertops have no back support, the couch is getting old (right before our eyes), and the hall closet is...actually pretty comfortable and quiet.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Point being: It might be time to upgrade the way things look and feel around here. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.bludot.com/?utm_source=MorningBrew&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=StayHomeSale&utm_content=Stash" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Blu Dot</a> creates modern furniture that’s unique, useful, and beautiful down to every last angle and line. In fact, <strong style="color:#000">each piece is imagined in their Minneapolis studio</strong> where they distort, test, and tweak until they’ve achieved something that goes well beyond the ordinary. It’s extraordinary.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.bludot.com/?utm_source=MorningBrew&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=StayHomeSale&utm_content=Stash" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Blu Dot’s</a> goal is to bring good design to as many people as possible, and to achieve that, they’re offering <strong style="color:#000">20% off all orders through May 3</strong>. This almost never happens—hence this revelatory piece of copywriting.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Time to put the blanket fort away for good. </p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CONSUMER GOODS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/23/consumer-goods-earnings-show-stockpiling-less-personal-grooming?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Consumers Are Stockpiling and Stinky
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s our takeaway from Unilever’s and Hershey’s earnings reports yesterday. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">First, Unilever</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The maker of half your grocery store haul (including Dove, Lipton tea, and Ben & Jerry’s) <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-melts-demand-for-unilevers-ice-cream-11587633932?mod=business_lead_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said sales</a> in North America grew 4.8% and online sales surged 36% as people restocked their cabinets. But in emerging markets, where airtight lockdowns dinged demand, sales dropped 1.8%. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>India, Unilever’s second-largest market, implemented some of the world's strictest limits.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And...now that more people are WFH, consumers are buying less shampoo and deodorant. If that’s you, please reevaluate—your roommates may not determine your salary, but they have noses. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Second, the chocolate mongers </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hershey’s <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/hershey-sales-miss-analysts-expectations-11587643209?mod=business_lead_pos12&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">missed by a kiss</a> on the top and bottom lines. It cut $271 million in profit, down from $304 million last year, though stockpilers gave it a nearly 11% retail sales boost in the four weeks before April 4. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Plunging international demand + closed schools, restaurants, and malls = tough times.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In even more bad news for the world’s roommates, Hershey’s gum and mint sales dropped 50%. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Unilever CFO Graeme Pitkethly said he expects the shifts in consumer behavior to continue after lockdowns end.</p>

for small businesses through the Paycheck Protection Program.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNow, you really have to \u003cem\u003etry \u003c/em\u003eif you want to make people angry while doling out $350 billion in emergency cash, but the first edition of PPP managed to do that and more. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNo room for VIPPPs \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs if dealing with line-cutters at the grocery store isn’t bad enough, recent reports have exposed how big banks \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/22/business/sba-loans-ppp-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eprioritized\u003c/a\u003e or offered unfair advantages to wealthy clients to secure PPP loans. Special treatment included \"concierge\" services and digital HOV lanes that zipped by clogged application portals. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eLoans of $1 million or more accounted for 45% of total PPP distributions...but ended up in the hands of just 4% of recipients. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThis time around,\u003c/strong\u003e $60 billion will be \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/house-expected-pass-latest-coronavirus-aid-bill-thursday-n1190376?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eset aside\u003c/a\u003e for mom-and-pop shops without a direct line to Midtown East. Many small businesses had better luck going through smaller/local banks in V1. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eKeeping things private \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePublicly traded companies \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/public-companies-have-to-repay-small-business-rescue-loans-11587670442?mod=hp_lead_pos6\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereceived\u003c/a\u003e almost $600 million in PPP loans—and a very public flogging for doing so. Some recipients, including Shake Shack and the owner of Ruth’s Chris Steakhouse, have agreed to return the money. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCritics argue these companies can raise funds through other avenues unavailable to mom and pop. Just last week, Shake Shack was able to raise $150 million selling new shares.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBut...they technically weren’t breaking any rules.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe National Restaurant Association \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-restaurant-hotel-chains-won-exemption-to-get-small-business-loans-11586167200?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elobbied\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e and helped secure exemptions from Congress for restaurants and hotel chains to access the PPP. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the SBA \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/23/small-business-loans-sba-203846?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eclosed the loophole\u003c/a\u003e and warned publicly traded companies they probably won't qualify for the new funds. The Treasury Department asked public companies to return their loans before May 7, or else face charges they weren’t acting “in good faith.”  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we’re here:\u003c/strong\u003e The SBA is currently not releasing detailed information about PPP recipients. However, the Fed (which also runs emergency small business lending programs) said yesterday it will \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-23/fed-to-name-participants-in-cares-act-backed-loan-programs?sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edisclose\u003c/a\u003e participants’ names, funding, and interest rates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA document posted on the World Health Organization’s website yesterday delivered some \u003ca href=\"https://www.statnews.com/2020/04/23/data-on-gileads-remdesivir-released-by-accident-show-no-benefit-for-coronavirus-patients/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edisappointing news\u003c/a\u003e: Remdesivir, a potential COVID-19 treatment developed by biopharma company Gilead Sciences, did not improve patient outcomes in a randomized clinical trial.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAccording to the summary, 13.9% of the patients who received the drug died after one month, versus 12.8% in a control group, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/0a4872d1-4cac-4040-846f-ce32daa09d99?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe FT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e and health news site Stat report. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe twist: \u003c/strong\u003eThe summary was quickly removed from the website. A WHO spokesperson said it was posted by mistake. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe study, a first-of-its-kind clinical trial in China, was stopped early because it didn’t have enough patients, so Gilead argued its results are inconclusive. Although Gilead did say “trends in the data suggest a potential benefit” for the drug. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo...what does it all mean? \u003c/strong\u003eNot much—no definitive thumbs up or down for remdesivir yet. offering \u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/netflix-raise-1-billion-debt-offering-1234587050/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$1 billion\u003c/a\u003e in junk bonds to feed its quarantine content machine. The company reported astounding subscriber numbers for Q1 when its home screen became the only game in town.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSnap, \u003c/strong\u003ealso looking to pounce on the best quarter for scrolling ever, is \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/snapchat-debt-offering-750-million-raise-70d55da3-c8c7-4c5e-a5f4-eebb20a8dab2.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eplanning to raise\u003c/a\u003e up to $750 million in private debt. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDelta \u003c/strong\u003eis planning to raise $3 billion in debt after \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-delta-air-offering/delta-to-raise-3-billion-in-debt-to-combat-virus-fallout-idUSKCN22500Q?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eforecasting\u003c/a\u003e a 90% revenue drop in Q2. On the other side of the battered travel sector, \u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eExpedia \u003c/strong\u003eis pulling in $2 billion in \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/23/expedia-raises-3-2b-to-ride-out-pandemic-names-new-ceo-and-announces-austerity-measures/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew debt financing\u003c/a\u003e (along with $1.2 billion in private equity funding). The company also named vice chairman Peter Kern as CEO.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMacy’s \u003c/strong\u003eis in perhaps even more trouble. Using its inventory and real estate as collateral, it’s considering raising as much as $5 billion in debt, \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/21/macys-weighs-raising-as-much-as-5-billion-in-debt-to-weather-coronavirus-crisis.html?mod=article_inline\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCNBC reports\u003c/a\u003e. Macy’s has furloughed most of its 130,000 employees while all of its stores have been closed since March 18.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s our takeaway from Unilever’s and Hershey’s earnings reports yesterday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe maker of half your grocery store haul (including Dove, Lipton tea, and Ben \u0026 Jerry’s) \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-melts-demand-for-unilevers-ice-cream-11587633932?mod=business_lead_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid sales\u003c/a\u003e in North America grew 4.8% and online sales surged 36% as people restocked their cabinets. But in emerging markets, where airtight lockdowns dinged demand, sales dropped 1.8%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIndia, Unilever’s second-largest market, implemented some of the world's strictest limits.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd...now that more people are WFH, consumers are buying less shampoo and deodorant. If that’s you, please reevaluate—your roommates may not determine your salary, but they have noses. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSecond, the chocolate mongers \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHershey’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/hershey-sales-miss-analysts-expectations-11587643209?mod=business_lead_pos12\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emissed by a kiss\u003c/a\u003e on the top and bottom lines. It cut $271 million in profit, down from $304 million last year, though stockpilers gave it a nearly 11% retail sales boost in the four weeks before April 4. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePlunging international demand + closed schools, restaurants, and malls =
